content: Which ancient civilization built the famous city of Machu Picchu, located high in the Andes Mountains of modern-day Peru?

Machu Picchu, the iconic ancient city nestled high in the Andes Mountains of modern-day Peru, was built by the Inca civilization. The Incas were a remarkable pre-Columbian society that flourished in South America from the early 13th century until the Spanish conquest in the 16th century.

Machu Picchu, often referred to as the "Lost City of the Incas," was constructed in the 15th century during the reign of the Inca emperor Pachacuti. Its exact purpose remains a subject of scholarly debate, but it is believed to have served as a royal estate or sacred religious site for Inca rulers.

The city is renowned for its sophisticated dry-stone walls that fuse huge blocks without the use of mortar, its intricate terraced agriculture, and its stunning architecture that harmoniously integrates into the natural landscape. Machu Picchu's location, perched on a mountain ridge above the Urubamba Valley, also provided strategic advantages for the Inca Empire.

Despite being known locally, Machu Picchu was largely unknown to the outside world until it was brought to international attention by American historian Hiram Bingham in 1911. Since then, it has become an iconic symbol of the Inca Empire and one of the most visited tourist destinations in South America.

In 1983, Machu Picchu was designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, recognizing its significant cultural and historical value. It is also one of the New Seven Wonders of the World, cementing its status as an architectural and engineering marvel of the ancient world.

The Inca civilization, of which Machu Picchu is a prominent example, was known for its advanced techniques in agriculture, architecture, and astronomy. Their empire once stretched across a vast territory, encompassing parts of present-day Peru, Ecuador, Bolivia, Chile, and Argentina.

Today, Machu Picchu stands as a testament to the ingenuity and craftsmanship of the Inca people, offering invaluable insights into their way of life and their remarkable achievements in various fields.
